title: 109_hr5820
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Agency Data Privacy Protection Act" and defines sensitive data. The "Federal Agency Data Privacy Protection Act" defines sensitive data to include social security numbers, financial records, health records, criminal records, licenses, tax returns, and personally identifiable information. The "Federal Agency Data Privacy Protection Act" defines personally identifiable information as any information related to an individual's physical or mental health or the provision of health care. SEC. 3. REQUIREMENT FOR USE OF ENCRYPTION FOR SENSITIVE DATA. Requirement for Encryption: All sensitive data held by the Federal Government must be secured using the most secure encryption standard recognized by NIST. Encryption keys must be changed every 6 months for added security. Agencies must comply with these requirements within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The requirement for complying with encryption standards within federal agencies is considered a requirement of the relevant section of the United States Code. SEC. 4. REQUIREMENTS RELATING TO ACCESS BY AGENCY PERSONNEL TO SENSITIVE DATA. Access to sensitive data by Federal government employees is restricted to those with a security clearance at the "secret" level or higher. Off-site access requires approval from the agency's Inspector General. The Inspector General must approve or disapprove off-site access requests within 2 business days. If approved, access is limited to 10,000 records at a time and must use the most secure encryption standard. Implementation of these requirements must occur within 6 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5 of the Act requires government contractors dealing with sensitive data of 10,000 or more US citizens to comply with specified requirements. This applies to contracts entered into six months after the Act's enactment.
